work.name: Dark Blue Therapeutics
work.summary: Molecular biology and bioinformatics in a small biotech company focused on novel, academic research-backed drug discovery programmes.
highlights: Bioinformatics to generate mechanistic insights on lead compounds, informing on viable patient populations, and new target evaluation.
AWS S3 data storage management and AWS batch operation with Nextflow.
Dotmatics ELN administration and development of data processing protocols that support compound screening efforts.
Development of molecular biology assays to evaluate compound activity that have been adopted into compound screening pipeline.
CRISPR Cas9 genome editing to generate cell line models for mechanistic studies.

work.name: de Bruijn lab, University of Oxford
work.summary: Short-term postdoctoral position in the de Bruijn lab, focusing on gene regulatory network modelling in embryonic haematopoiesis.
highlights: Analysis of single-cell RNA+ATAC multiomics in embryonic haematopoiesis to support ongoing lab projects.
ChIPmentation and ATAC-seq library preparation and analysis on rare embryonic haematopoietic populations.
Development of gene regulatory network models to identify key transcription factors in haematopoietic specification.
Training DPhil students in bioinformatics analysis and NGS library preparation techniques.

work.name: de Bruijn lab, University of Oxford
work.summary: Research assistant position, performing routine lab management, mouse husbandry, bioinformatics, and histology.
highlights: Routine wetlab support with mouse husbandry, routine genotyping, dissections, and histology.
Routine lab management: ordering, risk assessments, equipment training, etc.
CRISPR Cas9 genome editing to generate cell line models for mechanistic studies.
Bioinformatics and computational biology to support various lab projects.

education.summary: Thesis title: Regulatory network analyses highlight transcription factor cooperation in haematopoiesis and leukaemogenesis. Supervised by Professor Tom Milne and Professor Marella de Bruijn.
highlights: Received commendation for outstanding thesis and published first author paper in Genome Research.
Development analysis of gene regulatory network models in normal and malignant haematopoiesis incorporating multiomics data at bulk and single-cell resolution.
Application of CRISPR Cas9 genome editing and molecular biology techniques, in vitro and in mouse studies, to validate key network predictions.
Supervised two masters students in genome editing and bioinformatics projects.

education.summary: Dissertation title: Investigating the therapeutic effects of cannabinoids on chemotherapy induced muscle cachexia. Supervised by Professor Ketan Patel.
Dissertation title: Investigating the role of intermediate filaments of the cytoskeleton in skeletal muscle stem cell migration. Supervised by Professor Ketan Patel.

publications.name: A KMT2A-AFF1 gene regulatory network highlights the role of core transcription factors and reveals the regulatory logic of key downstream target genes
publications.summary: First author publication of early-DPhil work. This study identifies a gene regulatory network involving KMT2A and AFF1, two key transcription factors in leukaemia, and elucidates their downstream target genes.
